The home team tried to prevail using combination football, while the away side adopted a defensive style of play.
    

    #######TASK 
    Provide a factually correct and detailed textual description of the game compiled from the information presented above from different sources, in more than 1000 words.
            "Cap:": represents the captions published in the online portal usually within 30 seconds of the event.
            "E:" represents events recorded exactly after the event happened.
    Don't mention sources of information like commentators or captions, write as if you saw them live.
summary:
In a commanding display, Bayern Munich hosted Eintracht Frankfurt at the Allianz Arena, ultimately securing a decisive 3-0 victory. The match showcased Bayern's tactical prowess and offensive strength, while Eintracht Frankfurt struggled to contain the relentless onslaught from the home side.

The game commenced with Bayern Munich kicking off and instantly taking control of the ball. However, within mere seconds, Eintracht committed the first of many fouls, resulting in an indirect free-kick for Bayern. The early exchanges were marked by multiple instances of the ball going out of play, with both teams utilizing throw-ins to restart play.

At the one-minute mark, Bayern Munich looked to build momentum, but a foul committed by them followed shortly, and they were penalized with a yellow card. This only seemed to fire up the Bayern squad, who continued to push forward with intent. Despite being awarded a free-kick into the penalty area by Xabi Alonso, Eintracht's defense managed to intercept the cross valiantly.

As the minutes ticked by, Bayern solidified their dominance with steady ball possession but continuously encountered tough defensive maneuvers by Eintracht. At the 14th minute, Bayern’s persistence paid off when Thomas Muller provided a headed pass to Robert Lewandowski. Lewandowski expertly struck the ball from the edge of the box, sending it past Eintracht's goalkeeper Kevin Trapp to open the scoring.

Following the goal, Eintracht rekindled their efforts and immediately resumed from the kick-off, only for Bayern Munich to once again assert their authority through another series of fouls that earned them several free-kicks. Xabi Alonso took a series of free kicks, aiming to surprise Eintracht's defense, but goalkeeper Kevin Trapp remained resilient, making a series of crucial saves.

Again, Bayern Munich kept their offensive pressure high. Thomas Muller and Lewandowski both continued to test Trapp’s capabilities with on-target shots. Nevertheless, Trapp’s quick reflexes repeatedly came to Eintracht’s rescue. Despite Lewandowski's several promising efforts near the goal and a notable attempt at long-range shooting by Thiago Alcantara, the scoreline remained unchanged for a spell.

Eintracht’s only palpable threat in this half emerged when Sonny Kittel's solo run culminated in a shot that was expertly saved by Pepe Reina. Any illusion of balance in the game was short-lived as Bayern recommenced their attacking pursuits. Subsequently, attempts by Mario Gotze and Juan Bernat produced some near misses, and shots on target, but these were either saved or went off target.

The game saw several disruptions from fouls. Players on both sides received cautionary yellow cards, and Eintracht Frankfurt's Timothy Chandler earned himself one for a rugged challenge. As the game edged close to halftime, an injury scare hit Bayern’s Thiago Alcantara, necessitating a brief medical intervention.

The halftime whistle blew with Bayern Munich holding a solid 1-0 lead, underscoring their clear advantage from the first 45 minutes. The second half resumed with Eintracht kicking off. They tried to seize an early opportunity, but a misdirected shot by Haris Seferovic went wide off the right post. Nelson Valdez also attempted a bold strike that sailed over the crossbar, highlighting Eintracht’s inability to convert scarce opportunities into goals.

Back in their groove, Bayern Munich merged passing accuracy and strategic play. Every time Eintracht tried to regroup, Bayern’s defensive line, consisting of players like Rafinha, Juan Bernat, and Xabi Alonso, thwarted their advances. Meanwhile, Bayern's menacing attack resumed with intense vigor. 

A corner by Bayern resulted in a rebounded ball falling to Thiago, whose ambitious long-range shot flew over the bar. The game then witnessed a string of substitutions aimed at rejuvenating both sides with fresh legs. For Bayern, Sebastian Rode replaced Thiago Alcantara. Eintracht made multiple changes too, with Takashi Inui and Lucas Piazon joining the fray for Nelson Valdez and Stefan Aigner, respectively. Alexander Ignjovski also substituted Bamba Anderson.

Bayern Munich's attacks were relentless, characterized by well-timed crosses and intelligent positioning. Robert Lewandowski once again surfaced as Bayern's talisman, doubling their lead at the hour mark. Lewandowski headed home a goal following a corner that saw Trapp initially make a save only for the ball to be rebounded and finished by Lewandowski. This goal emphasized Bayern’s lethal efficiency in capitalizing on set-piece situations.

The visitor's frustrations were evident as Marc Stendera found himself booked for dissent. A few minutes later, Timothy Chandler joined him in the book following a trip. Shortly afterward, Mario Gotze rattled the goalpost, narrowly missing a chance to further extend the lead. 

Later, Bayern made positional changes to preserve their vigor as Holger Badstuber replaced Rafinha, showcasing tactical flexibility to strengthen the backline. It was a successful move as the home side continued to aggressively control the midfield and defensive zones alike. 

With the clock ticking towards the final whistle, Bayern Munich put the game beyond any doubt. They netted their third goal through Thomas Muller, who pounced on an opportunity inside the box and made no mistake, decisively slamming the ball into the right post. 

Although Bayern Munich had more opportunities to increase their tally, including several close-range shots and corner set-pieces, Kevin Trapp kept the score at bay, illustrating his resilient goalkeeping prowess. 

Another notable moment occurred when Robert Lewandowski hit the post yet again, displaying extraordinary offensive pressure but was slightly unlucky not to secure a hat trick. In their attempts to salvage some pride, Eintracht's attacks remained dismally inefficient as Bayern’s defensive coherence left them without scope to threaten consistently.

The game concluded with Eintracht Frankfurt earning a late yellow card for a harsh tackle by Ignjovski, further highlighting their struggle to maintain discipline under Bayern’s persistent push.

As the full-time whistle approached, Bayern Munich was firmly in control, the fans at Allianz Arena celebrated a well-deserved 3-0 victory. This match was emblematic of Bayern's high-flying ambitions — a robust combination of tactical supremacy, offensive flair, and defensive rigidity that left little room for Frankfurt's aspirations.

Both teams demonstrated remarkable sporting spirit, but it was Bayern’s tactical ingenuity and cohesive team play that commanded the game. Their precise passing, decisive set-piece execution, and aggressive forward moves were key elements of their impressive win. The match left an indelible mark on the spectators, exemplifying the thrilling nature and competitive spirit of top-flight soccer.
